posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: The robot's elevator subsystem consistently reports an encoder reading of 0 despite the elevator moving. We attempted various troubleshooting methods including verifying the connection between the encoder and the RoboRIO hardware, ensuring power and ground connections are correctly set, and testing different configurations for the encoder. Additionally, we confirmed that the elevator motors are functioning properly and that the encoder shaft is rotating as expected. Our tests indicated that simply changing the minimum rate samples to average did not resolve the issue. Further investigation is required to identify the cause of the persistent zero reading.

Are you using the encoder as a relative encoder? If you are using it as an absolute encoder, you need to use the DutyCycleEncoder class. Make sure you are connecting the right wires for how you want to use it. The documentation for that can be found here https://docs.revrobotics.com/rev-crossover-products/sensors/tbe/application-examples

posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: I used the Quadrature Encoder (Relative) as described in the documentation and switched it to mode A.
In your robot.java file, where is the resetEncoder method being called?
You added an integer when resetting the encoder, which might cause the system to truncate decimal values. Try setting it back to 0.0 to see if that resolves the issue.

posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: i changed SmartDashboard.putNumber("Ela", 0) to SmartDashboard.putNumber("Ela", 0.0) but still got zero

posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: Also, I tried unplugging and replugging the encoder during runtime, which caused a slight change in the ela value.
Could you post a link to your GitHub so I can have more context.

I don‚Äôt see anything that would be causing this. I think you could check the raw count of the encoder to verify if data is being received and rule out a smart dashboard issue (something I doubt). If that doesn‚Äôt resolve it, it might relate to an electrical problem.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: Whenever I get this issue, it's because the sensor wires that connect into the rev throughbore encoder aren't in enough. I doubt that will work in your case since you've already double-checked the wiring, but it's worth a try.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: You could wire the index pulse to a digital input. It‚Äôs easy to see that pulse at 90 degrees, and it could indicate if the encoder has power and is performing useful functions.
